title: Local Git Commands
text:
Thanks Cottle for creating this educational tool. Ever thought of Git graphs as linked lists? Here is a great explanation.
First things first,

title: Local Git Commands
text:
git commit
This creates a new commit C1, which references where it was based off of — in this case, a C0 which is a initial commit becomes the parent.
git commit










flowchart TB
  main:::pointer -.-> C0:::commit
  HEAD:::pointer -.-> main
  classDef commit fill: #abc, color: #000
  classDef pointer fill: #fff, color #000, font: #000











flowchart TB
  C1:::commit --> C0:::commit
  main:::pointer -.-> C1
  HEAD:::pointer -.-> main
  classDef commit fill: #abc, color: #000
  classDef pointer fill: #fff, color #000, font: #000

title: Local Git Commands
text:
git branch
Branches is Git are simply pointers to a specific commit – nothing more. This is why many Git enthusiasts chant the mantra

branch early, and branch often.

When we start mixing branches (pointers) and commits, we will see how these two features combine. For now, just remember that a branch essentially says

I want to include the work of this commit and all parent commits.

git checkout main
git branch dev










flowchart TB
  C1:::commit --> C0:::commit
  main:::pointer -.-> C1
  HEAD:::pointer -.-> main
  classDef commit fill: #abc, color: #000
  classDef pointer fill: #fff, color #000, font: #000











flowchart TB
  C1:::commit --> C0:::commit
  main:::pointer -.-> C1
  dev:::pointer -.-> C1
  HEAD:::pointer -.-> main
  classDef commit fill: #abc, color: #000
  classDef pointer fill: #fff, color #000, font: #000








git checkout main
git checkout -b dev
git checkout main
git switch -c dev










flowchart TB
  C1:::commit --> C0:::commit
  main:::pointer -.-> C1
  HEAD:::pointer -.-> main
  classDef commit fill: #abc, color: #000
  classDef pointer fill: #fff, color #000, font: #000











flowchart TB
  C1:::commit --> C0:::commit
  main:::pointer -.-> C1
  dev:::pointer -.-> C1
  HEAD:::pointer -.-> dev
  classDef commit fill: #abc, color: #000
  classDef pointer fill: #fff, color #000, font: #000

title: Local Git Commands
text:
git merge
merge command eventually creates a special commit which has two unique parents. A commit with two parents essentially means

I want to include all the work from both parents, and the set of all their parents.

git checkout main
1git merge dev
git checkout dev
2git merge main

1

The command merges dev branch into the current main branch. This leaves the dev branch (pointer) behind.

2

We don’t need to derive the work from both the main and dev parents again because the dev graph is a subgraph of the main graph. Instead, we can simply move the dev pointer to match the position of the main pointer. This is also called fast forward.












flowchart TB
  C1:::commit --> C0:::commit
  C2:::commit --> C1:::commit
  C3:::commit --> C1:::commit
  main:::pointer -.-> C2
  dev:::pointer -.-> C3
  HEAD:::pointer -.-> main
  classDef commit fill: #abc, color: #000
  classDef pointer fill: #fff, color #000, font: #000











flowchart TB
  C1:::commit --> C0:::commit
  C2:::commit --> C1:::commit
  C3:::commit --> C1:::commit
  C4:::commit --> C2:::commit
  C4:::commit --> C3:::commit

  main:::pointer -.-> C4
  dev:::pointer -.-> C3
  HEAD:::pointer -.-> main
  classDef commit fill: #abc, color: #000
  classDef pointer fill: #fff, color #000, font: #000











flowchart TB
  C1:::commit --> C0:::commit
  C2:::commit --> C1:::commit
  C3:::commit --> C1:::commit
  C4:::commit --> C2:::commit
  C4:::commit --> C3:::commit

  main:::pointer -.-> C4
  dev:::pointer -.-> C3
  HEAD:::pointer -.-> dev
  classDef commit fill: #abc, color: #000
  classDef pointer fill: #fff, color #000, font: #000











flowchart TB
  C1:::commit --> C0:::commit
  C2:::commit --> C1:::commit
  C3:::commit --> C1:::commit
  C4:::commit --> C2:::commit
  C4:::commit --> C3:::commit

  main:::pointer -.-> C4
  dev:::pointer -.-> C4
  HEAD:::pointer -.-> dev
  classDef commit fill: #abc, color: #000
  classDef pointer fill: #fff, color #000, font: #000

title: Local Git Commands
text:
git rebase
rebase copies the commits and stack them on somewhere else.






Note



The position of the HEAD pointer is different when merging and rebasing.
git checkout main # <- HEAD
git merge dev
git checkout dev # <- HEAD
git rebase main
When rebasing, we are willing to rebase with copied commits onto main.


git checkout dev
git rebase main
git checkout main
git merge dev










flowchart TB
  C1:::commit --> C0:::commit
  C2:::commit --> C1:::commit
  C3:::commit --> C1:::commit
  C4:::commit --> C3:::commit
  main:::pointer -.-> C2
  dev:::pointer -.-> C4
  HEAD:::pointer -.-> dev
  classDef commit fill: #abc, color: #000
  classDef pointer fill: #fff, color #000, font: #000











flowchart TB
  C1:::commit --> C0:::commit
  C2:::commit --> C1:::commit
  C3':::commit --> C2:::commit
  C4':::commit --> C3':::commit
  main:::pointer -.-> C2
  dev:::pointer -.-> C4'
  HEAD:::pointer -.-> dev
  classDef commit fill: #abc, color: #000
  classDef pointer fill: #fff, color #000, font: #000











flowchart TB
  C1:::commit --> C0:::commit
  C2:::commit --> C1:::commit
  C3':::commit --> C2:::commit
  C4':::commit --> C3':::commit
  main:::pointer -.-> C2
  dev:::pointer -.-> C4'
  HEAD:::pointer -.-> main
  classDef commit fill: #abc, color: #000
  classDef pointer fill: #fff, color #000, font: #000











flowchart TB
  C1:::commit --> C0:::commit
  C2:::commit --> C1:::commit
  C3':::commit --> C2:::commit
  C4':::commit --> C3':::commit
  main:::pointer -.-> C4'
  dev:::pointer -.-> C4'
  HEAD:::pointer -.-> main
  classDef commit fill: #abc, color: #000
  classDef pointer fill: #fff, color #000, font: #000

title: Local Git Commands
text:
git checkout
Didn’t we use the git checkout command without any discomfort so far? What checkout does is point HEAD to the desired object such as a branch or a commit.
git checkout 1b7979e16daafabf7c052411b083ea9e2e8a13d5

Relative reference (^ and ~)
git checkout C1
git checkout C2^
git checkout main^^
git checkout main~2
git checkout HEAD^; git checkout HEAD^










flowchart TB
  C1:::commit --> C0:::commit
  C2:::commit --> C1:::commit
  C3:::commit --> C2:::commit
  main:::pointer -.-> C3
  HEAD:::pointer -.-> main
  classDef commit fill: #abc, color: #000
  classDef pointer fill: #fff, color #000, font: #000











flowchart TB
  C1:::commit --> C0:::commit
  C2:::commit --> C1:::commit
  C3:::commit --> C2:::commit
  main:::pointer -.-> C3
  HEAD:::pointer -.-> C1
  classDef commit fill: #abc, color: #000
  classDef pointer fill: #fff, color #000, font: #000










Branch forcing (git branch -f)
git branch -f feature dev^










flowchart TB
  C1:::commit --> C0:::commit
  C2:::commit --> C1:::commit
  C3:::commit --> C1:::commit
  C4:::commit --> C3:::commit
  C5:::commit --> C4:::commit
  C6:::commit --> C5:::commit
  C7:::commit --> C4:::commit
  main:::pointer -.-> C2
  dev:::pointer -.-> C6
  feature:::pointer -.-> C7
  HEAD:::pointer -.-> main
  classDef commit fill: #abc, color: #000
  classDef pointer fill: #fff, color #000, font: #000











flowchart TB
  C1:::commit --> C0:::commit
  C2:::commit --> C1:::commit
  C3:::commit --> C1:::commit
  C4:::commit --> C3:::commit
  C5:::commit --> C4:::commit
  C6:::commit --> C5:::commit
  main:::pointer -.-> C2
  dev:::pointer -.-> C6
  feature:::pointer -.-> C5
  HEAD:::pointer -.-> main
  classDef commit fill: #abc, color: #000
  classDef pointer fill: #fff, color #000, font: #000

title: .kube/config
text:
I have set up Minikube on my MacBook for an easy development environment, and at home, I have a Raspberry Pi cluster set up for my homelab. These configurations allow me to access and manage my clusters from anywhere. Specifically, I have properly configured the .kube/config file to enable remote access to the cluster at home.
Below is an example of the configured .kube/config file:


.kube/config


apiVersion: v1
clusters:
- cluster:
    certificate-authority-data: LS0...LS0tCg==
    server: https://kubernetes.docker.internal:6443
  name: docker-desktop
- cluster:
    insecure-skip-tls-verify: true
    server: https://121.135.111.111:6443
  name: raspberrypi
- cluster:
    certificate-authority: /Users/shane/.minikube/ca.crt
    extensions:
    - extension:
        last-update: Sun, 20 Aug 2023 17:04:00 KST
        version: v1.30.1
        provider: minikube.sigs.k8s.io
      name: cluster_info
    server: https://127.0.0.1:60544
  name: minikube

The above configuration file defines three clusters:

docker-desktop
raspberrypi (the Raspberry Pi cluster at home, with the server address https://121.135.111.111:6443)
minikube

With this configuration file, you can easily access various clusters using the kubectl command. For example, to access the Raspberry Pi cluster, you can use the following command:
kubectl config use-context raspberrypi
To bypass the process of verifying the SSL certificate as a public certificate, use the following command:
- cluster:
    insecure-skip-tls-verify: true

title: Git Prompt
text:
Turn this  user@host gitrepo $  into this  user@host gitrepo (main) $ .
Download the git-prompt.sh with the curl command.
curl https://raw.githubusercontent.com/git/git/master/contrib/completion/git-prompt.sh -o ~/.git-prompt.sh
Then add the following lines in the .zshrc file.


.zshrc

source ~/.git-prompt.sh
setopt PROMPT_SUBST
PS1='%n@%m %c%F{green}$(__git_ps1 " (%s)")%f \$ '

title: Tmux
text: Start off with installing tmux with homebrew on Mac.

title: Tmux
text:
Intro
There are three main concepts in tmux: session, window, and pane. Start by entering tmux in the terminal.
The screen you see right after entering the command is a pane in a window.

title: Tmux
text:
Pane
Split the pane using Ctrl-bCtrl-b %% and Ctrl-bCtrl-b "".
The Ctrl-bCtrl-b works as a prefix to send a command — later below.
Navigate through the panes using Ctrl-bCtrl-b ↑↑, Ctrl-bCtrl-b →→, Ctrl-bCtrl-b ↓↓, Ctrl-bCtrl-b ←←.

title: Tmux
text:
Window
Open a new window with Ctrl-bCtrl-b cc.
See the windows you opened on the bottom green bar? This gives us some information about the windows in the session. The current window you are seeing is marked with an *.
Navigate through the windows using Ctrl-bCtrl-b nn — n is for next. This will cycle through all the windows in the current session. Reverse navigate with Ctrl-bCtrl-b pp — p is for previous. You can also navigate directly to a window using the index. The bindings will be like Ctrl-bCtrl-b 11.

title: Tmux
text:
Session
From the very first, right after the tmux command, you are attached to a session with an auto generated index. Detach the session with the Ctrl-bCtrl-b dd command — and d is for detach. It’s almost the same as starting the bash session and detaching with the exit command. Tmux can also be detached using the exit command, but this can be tedious because each split pane needs to be closed individually with the exit command.

title: Tmux
text:
Configurations
Feeling comfortable with the keybindings? I hope not. The default keybindings can put significant stress on your left pinky. This brings us to the .tmux.conf file for some configuration.


~/.tmux.conf

unbind-key C-b
set -g prefix C-a
1bind-key C-a send-prefix

2set -g mouse on
3set -g base-index 1
set -g renumber-windows on
set -g default-terminal "tmux-256color"

4bind r source-file ~/.tmux.conf \; display-message ".tmux.conf reloaded!"

5bind '\' split-window -h -c "#{pane_current_path}"
6bind - split-window -v -c "#{pane_current_path}"

7bind h select-pane -L
bind j select-pane -D
bind k select-pane -U
bind l select-pane -R

8bind x kill-pane
9bind X kill-window


1

Replace the prefix key from Ctrl-bCtrl-b to Ctrl-aCtrl-a. When you are using a keyboard like HHKB, this will come in pretty handy. Let’s talk more about HHKB in some other posts.

2

Pretty straight forward. Helps you navigate split panes with a mouse.

3

The default is 0. For me, 0 key is a bit far for everyday use.

4

Reload the .tmux.conf file and display a message when done — similar to something like source .bashrc.

5

Split the window horizontally using the current pane’s path.

6

Split the window vertically using the current pane’s path.

7

Move between panes using Vim-style keybindings.

8

Kill the current pane.

9

Kill the current window.


Personal preference on the following one.


.zshrc

tmux() {
    if [ "$#" -eq 0 ]; then
1        command tmux new-session -A -s default
    else
        command tmux "$@"
    fi
}


1

Attach a session named default when tmux is typed.
